document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the subgenus Aleochara Gravenhorst of the parasitoid rove beetle genus Aleochara Gravenhorst of Japan (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the subgenus Aleochara Gravenhorst of the parasitoid rove beetle genus Aleochara Gravenhorst of Japan (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Staphylinus curtulus
Goeze, 1777
: 730
(original description; type locality: unspecified in original description).

Aleochara curtula (
Goeze, 1777
)
;
Bernhauer & Scheerpeltz, 1926
: 776
[as subgenus
Aleochara
(s. str.); catalogue of world species of Aleocharinae ];
Klimaszewski, 1984
: 71
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; in key to North American species of subgenus
Aleochara
), 76 (redescription);
Welch, 1997
: 10
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; list of British species of
Aleochara
), 16 (in key to British species of genus
Aleochara
);
Ahn et al ., 2000
: 246
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; in key to Korean species of genus
Aleochara
);
Cho & Ahn, 2001
: 30
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; catalogue of Korean species of Silphidae and Staphylinidae );
Paśnik, 2001
: 230
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; record from North Korea );
Smetana, 2004 b
: 353
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; catalogue of Palearctic species of Aleocharinae );
Gouix & Klimaszewski, 2007
: 20
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; catalogue of Canadian and Alaskan species of Aleocharinae );
Park & Ahn, 2010 a
: 317
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; in key to Far-Eastern species of subgenus
Aleochara
);
Luo & Zhao, 2012
: 180
[as
Aleochara
(s. str.); in key to Chinese species of subgenus
Aleochara
], 193 (redescription);
Shibata et al ., 2013
: 105
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; catalogue of Korean species of Staphylinidae );
Klimaszewski et al ., 2013
: 57
(without subgeneric assignment; redescription; book of Canadian Staphylinidae );
Schülke & Smetana, 2015
: 491
(as subgenus
Aleochara
; catalogue of Palearctic species of Aleocharinae ).

Aleochara discoidea
Sharp, 1874
: 7
(original description; type locality: Japan , unspecified);
Bernhauer & Scheerpeltz, 1926
: 776
(as a synonym of
A. curtula
; catalogue of world species of Aleocharinae );
Klimaszewski, 1984
: 77
(as synonym of
A. curtula
; revision of Nearctic species of genus
Aleochara
);
Smetana, 2004 b
: 353
(as synonym of
A. curtula
; catalogue of Palearctic species of Aleocharinae );
Gouix & Klimaszewski, 2007
: 21
(as synonym of
A. curtula
; catalogue of Canadian and Alaskan species of Aleocharinae );
Luo & Zhao, 2012
: 194
(as synonym of
A. curtula
; revision of Chinese species of subgenus
Aleochara
);
Shibata et al ., 2013
: 105
(as synonym of
A. curtula
; catalogue of Japanese species of Staphylinidae );
Klimaszewski et al ., 2013
: 57
(as synonym of
A. curtula
);
Schülke & Smetana, 2015
: 491
(as synonym of
A. curtula
). Synonymy confirmed.

subSubSection.paragraph:
See
Klimaszewski ( 1984 )
for further references, especially those before
Klimaszewski ( 1984 )
.

Type material.
A.discoidea
: lectotype , here designated, female “ Type [RRL] // Japan / G. Lewis // Sharp Coll. / 1905 - 313 // Aleochara / discoidea / Type D.S. [HW] // Lectotype / Aleochara discoidea /
Sharp, 1874
/ des.
Maruyama, 2011
” (abdominal segments VIII-X and spermatheca dissected and mounted in Euparal by MM) ( BMNH ); paralectotype , female, “ Japan / G. Lewis // Sharp Coll. / 1905 - 313 // Aleochara / discoidea / Type D.S. [HW] // Lectotype / Aleochara discoidea /
Sharp, 1874
/ des.
Maruyama, 2011
” ( BMNH ).

A. curtula : Not
examined.

Diagnosis .
Aleochara curtula
most closely resembles
A. postica
externally due to the similar maculatedpatterns of elytra, but can be confidently separated by the following characteristics: elytra with prominent, blackish, and parallel sided maculations laterally on each side of elytra, reaching to shoulders of each elytron; median lobe of aedeagus bulbous, hook-like shaped at apex. In some cases,
A. curtula
can be erroneously identified as
A. parens
due to the similarity of the configuration of male genitalia, but can be easily distinguished from it as follows: usually much paler coloration in elytra, with distinct, black, and parallel sided maculations; median lobe of aedeagus of male with hook-like shaped apex of apical lobe, and by; deeply expanded apical invagination of female spermathecal head. Restricted to only mainland and adjacent large islands in Japan .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 52–53. Mouth parts of
Aleochara ( Aleochara ) curtula
of male: 52, labium; 53, maxilla (left, ventral). Scale bars: 0.1 mm (52); 0.2 mm (53).

subSubSection.paragraph: Body ( Figs 2 , 11 ): fusiform, robust, medium to large in size; dorsal surface moderately glossy and pubescent, without any types of micro-reticulation, but moderately rather coarsely punctured. Color ( Figs 2 , 11 ): usually uniformly black to blackish brown, but elytra variable in color pattern, generally reddish brown but infuscate laterally and basally to form distinct black maculations (almost parallel sided on each elytron); antennae with antennomeres I–II dark brown, antennomeres III to IV much darker, antennomeres V–XI slightly darker than those of I–II but covered with minute whitish setae densely; mouth parts and legs yellowish brown to brownish brown; pubescence yellowish brown to brown.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 54–57. Mouth parts of
Aleochara ( Aleochara ) curtula
of male: 54, mandible (right, dorsal view); 55, mentum; 56, labrum; 57, epipharynx (labrum, adoral view). Scale bars: 0.2 mm (54–57).

FIGURES 58–64. Terminalia of
Aleochara ( Aleochara ) curtula
: 58, male tergite VIII, dorsal view; 59, female tergite VIII, dorsal view; 60, male sternite VIII, ventral view; 61, female sternite VIII, ventral view; 62, median lobe of male aedeagus, lateral view; 63, ditto, parameral view; 64, female spermatheca. Scale bars: 0.5 mm (58–63); 0.1 mm (64).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Japan (Hokkaidô, Honshû, Shikoku, Kyûshû; Sadoga-shima Is., Miyake-jima Is., Tsu-shima Is.); Palearctic, Nearctic, Oriental, Afrotropical, and Neotropical regions.

Remarks for type material.
Two syntypes of
A. discoidea
were both females, one of which is designated as the lectotype here (
Fig. 110
).
Aleochara discoidea
has been regarded as a synonym of
A. curtula
(see
Klimaszewski, 1984
). The shape of the spermatheca of the lectotype agreed well with that of
A. curtula
; thus, synonymy was confirmed.

Comments. This is one of the commonest
Aleochara
species in Japan .
Klimaszewski ( 1984 )
provided informative redescription of this species.
Aleochara curtula
is a type species of the genus
Aleochara
and has a cosmopolitan distribution. Additionally, this species is found commonly worldwide and can be reared easily under laboratory conditions. Thus, countless studies in various fields have been carried out using
A. curtula
, especially in connection with male attractive chemicals, e.g., life history (see
Klimaszewski, 1984
; Peschke et al ., 1987 ); mating behavior (
Peschke, 1978
); male aggression, female mimicry and female choice (Peschke, 1987 ); female sex pheromones (e.g.,
Peschke & Metzler, 1987
;
Peschke et al ., 1999
); spermathecal morphology, sperm transfer, and sperm displacement (
Gack & Peschke, 1994
), and; functional morphology of the abdomen and male genitalia (
Peschke, 1978
). Recently, Misof et al . ( 2014 ) presented a phylogeny of all insects (Insecta) by conducting phylogenomic analyses based on transcriptomic data. In their study,
A. curtula
was chosen as the only staphylinoid representative and as one of eight representatives of coleopteran species (Misof et al ., 2014 ).
